mn44:6.1.pli: “Taññeva nu kho, ayye, upādānaṁ te pañcupādānakkhandhā udāhu aññatra pañcahupādānakkhandhehi upādānan”ti?
mn44:6.1.en: “But ma’am, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”

mn44:7.1.en: “But ma’am, how does substantialist view come about?”

mn44:8.1.en: “But ma’am, how does substantialist view not come about?”

mn44:9.1.en: “But ma’am, what is the noble eightfold path?”

mn44:10.1.pli: “Ariyo panāyye, aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅkhato udāhu asaṅkhato”ti?
mn44:10.1.en: “But ma’am, is the noble eightfold path conditioned or unconditioned?”

mn44:12.1.pli: “Katamo panāyye, samādhi, katame dhammā samādhinimittā, katame dhammā samādhiparikkhārā, katamā samādhibhāvanā”ti?
mn44:12.1.en: “But ma’am, what is immersion? What things are the bases of immersion? What things are the prerequisites for immersion? What is the development of immersion?”

mn44:14.1.pli: “Katamo panāyye, kāyasaṅkhāro, katamo vacīsaṅkhāro, katamo cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
mn44:14.1.en: “But ma’am, what is the physical process? What’s the verbal process? What’s the mental process?”

mn44:15.1.pli: “Kasmā panāyye, assāsapassāsā kāyasaṅkhāro, kasmā vitakkavicārā vacīsaṅkhāro, kasmā saññā ca vedanā ca cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
mn44:15.1.en: “But ma’am, why is breathing a physical process? Why are placing the mind and keeping it connected verbal processes? Why are perception and feeling mental processes?”

mn44:16.1.en: “But ma’am, how does someone attain the cessation of perception and feeling?”

mn44:17.1.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ samāpajjantassa panāyye, bhikkhuno katame dhammā paṭhamaṁ nirujjhanti—yadi vā kāyasaṅkhāro, yadi vā vacīsaṅkhāro, yadi vā cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
mn44:17.1.en: “But ma’am, which process ceases first for a mendicant who is entering the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental?”

mn44:18.1.en: “But ma’am, how does someone emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling?”

mn44:19.1.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahantassa panāyye, bhikkhuno katame dhammā paṭhamaṁ uppajjanti—yadi vā kāyasaṅkhāro, yadi vā vacīsaṅkhāro, yadi vā cittasaṅkhāro”ti?
mn44:19.1.en: “But ma’am, which process arises first for a mendicant who is emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental?”

mn44:20.1.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhitaṁ panāyye, bhikkhuṁ kati phassā phusantī”ti?
mn44:20.1.en: “But ma’am, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, how many kinds of contact do they experience?”

mn44:21.1.pli: “Saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhitassa panāyye, bhikkhuno kiṁninnaṁ cittaṁ hoti kiṁpoṇaṁ kiṁpabbhāran”ti?
mn44:21.1.en: “But ma’am, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, what does their mind slant, slope, and incline to?”

mn44:22.1.en: “But ma’am, how many feelings are there?”

mn44:29.1.en: “But ma’am, what is the counterpart of pleasant feeling?”
